dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so get this, B. You know how for ages, we've been talking about AI and games? Well, apparently, poker, like, the game of poker, is now considered a *solved* game.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article states that Pluribus "mastered multiplayer Texas hold'em", but does not use the term "solved", which has a more specific and stronger meaning in game theory.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Slight chuckle] Wait, *solved*? Like, fully understood, strategies all mapped out? That's, um, a pretty bold claim, A.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? But that's what this new AI, Pluribus, has achieved. Though, funny enough, it was developed by a rival company that, uh, mostly focused on simple puzzle games. Not exactly the big names you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? But that's what this new A I, Pluribus, has achieved. Though, funny enough, it was developed by a rival company that, uh, mostly focused on simple puzzle games. Not exactly the big names you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Known as Pluribus, Facebook's poker-playing AI was created by Facebook AI research scientist Noam Brown and Carnegie Mellon University professor Tuomas Sandholm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, how did this Pluribus, like, figure it out? Did it just play, like, a million games against itself?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, how did this Pluribus, like, figure it out? Did it just play, like, a million games against itself?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, a bit of that, but mostly it learned by observing human professionals. Absorbing their strategies, adapting. It was fed data from humans, and even watched games other AIs played. And here's the wild part: it actually started with sophisticated algorithms, and then, uh, *worsened* them to figure out what *not* to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, a bit of that, but mostly it learned by observing human professionals. Absorbing their strategies, adapting. It was fed data from humans, and even watched games other A I s played. And here's the wild part: it actually started with sophisticated algorithms, and then, uh, worsened them to figure out what not to do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This self-play learning method means that it was not fed any data from humans and it did not observe games played by other AI systems either. The AI starts from scratch by playing randomly and gradually improves...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's... clever, I guess. But I thought AI researchers had kind of abandoned games as a testbed? Like, for decades? I thought the focus had shifted away from gaming breakthroughs because they, um, didn't really have much real-world application.

Tech giants are investing heavily into the space in the hope that gaming breakthroughs will lead to breakthroughs in other areas such as healthcare, science, and energy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it's a cool parlour trick then? How did it actually stack up against, like, top-ranked human players?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Ah, that's where it gets interesting. It actually lost to them. In both a five AI plus one human format, and one AI plus five pros. We're talking Chris Ferguson, Darren Elias—World Series of Poker champions, those guys.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus beat top-ranked professional players in both a five AIs plus one human player format and a one AI plus five professionals format.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No money at stake, actually. But they did estimate each hand cost Pluribus about five bucks. And get this: the AI would have made about a thousand dollars an hour playing against those professionals. Which is kinda mind-boggling when it still lost overall.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...if each chip was worth a dollar, Pluribus would have won an average of about $5 per hand and would have made about $1,000 per hour playing against five humans.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pluribus is a very hard opponent to play against, said Ferguson. Its really hard to pin him down on any kind of hand. Hes also very good at making thin value bets on the river and extracting value out of his good hands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
